        "Views": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nDuring the late 1960s many university campuses across America experienced significant political and social turmoil.\u00a0 For the University of Illinois the spring of 1970 was a time of tremendous political unrest among students and faculty regarding America\u2019s involvement in the Vietnam war, the US Department of Defense\u2019s construction of the Illiac IV supercomputer on campus, the Champaign-Urbana police force\u2019s killing of an unarmed African American student on the Illinois campus, and the Ohio National Guard\u2019s shooting of four students on the campus of Kent State University. \u00a0\u00a0While Illinois\u2019 students and many of its faculty frequently came together at this time to protest the Federal government\u2019s growing political oppression and imperialism, the campus\u2019 activists and protestors used many different music genres to convey their messages across the Urbana-Champaign campus.\u00a0 Music groups like the Campus Folksong Club, the Walden String Quartet, Medicare 7, 8, or 9, and REO Speedwagon as well as many faculty members from the University\u2019s School of Music frequently lent their musical talents to support these political and social protests. \u00a0This exhibit of photographs, news clippings, advertisements, protest broadsides, concert programs, graphic illustrations, and audio recordings highlight the diverse intersections of music, art, and protest on the Illinois campus during the 1970 school year.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",

    {
        "Title": "Sousa Archives and Center for American Music, 1103 S. Sixth Street, Champaign",
        "Event Type": "Aug 21, 2017 - Aug 6, 2018 \u00a0  All Day ",
        "Sponsor": "sousa@illinois.edu",
        "Location": "217-244-9309",
        "Date ": "307",
        "Cost": "Library Calendar",
        "E-Mail ": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nThe Russian imperial capital of St. Petersburg was a major stop during John Philip Sousa\u2019s 1903 tour of Europe.\u00a0 Sousa planned his St. Petersburg performances to coincide with the tsar\u2019s birthday and the bicentennial of the city\u2019s founding, and anticipated large audiences for these concerts because the band had never before played in Russia.\u00a0 What resulted, however, was a misadventure.\u00a0 The concerts occurred at the beginning of Russia\u2019s annual summer vacation when most theaters and concerts halls were closed.\u00a0 In addition Russian music critics\u2019 responses to his music was tepid.\u00a0 Sousa was intimidated by the extensive advertising throughout the city for what he initially believed to be his music rival \u0421\u0443\u0437\u0430, but eventually discovered that this was the Russian spelling of his own name. \u00a0\u00a0While the St. Petersburg performances were not well attended, the concerts did spark deep patriotism among the American diplomats who were able to attend and the Russian aristocracy and military enthusiastically received the Sousa Band\u2019s renditions of the Imperial Russian and American national anthems.\u00a0 This exhibit of photographs, music, newspaper reviews, and political cartoons document Russian perceptions of America and Sousa\u2019s music at the beginning of the twentieth century.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",
        "Phone ": "Sousa and Tsar Nicholas II\u2019s Birthday: An Unexpected Tour Adventure",
        "Views": "art history, arts, conservation, graduate, medieval studies, provenance, research",

        "Title": "Spurlock Museum",
        "Event Type": "Spurlock Museum",
        "Sponsor": "Sep 12, 2017 - Aug 15, 2018 \u00a0  All Day ",

        "Date ": "Beth Watkins",
        "Cost": "ewatkins@illinois.edu",
        "E-Mail ": "217-265-5485",
        "Phone ": "399",
        "Views": "Campus General Request Event",
        "Originating Calendar": "The exhibit Knowledge at Work: The University of Illinois at 150 traces the connections between the University of Illinois and people, places, and ideas near and far. Explore this community of educators, researchers, and students over decades of learning, research, and public service. Learn about contributions of a wide variety of people and groups to campus history and ways the University has changed how it relates to the people it serves.\n\u00a0\nFrom its founding as a Land Grant institution in 1867 focused on agriculture and engineering, through expansions into arts, graduate studies, and national and international collaborations, the University has maintained a mission to deliver education and research in service to society. In Knowledge at Work, we look at the role of the University of Illinois as a nexus for bringing together people with diverse backgrounds, perspectives, and experiences in a common pursuit. The background and needs of students and faculty have changed over time, inspiring new facilities, curricula, and services.\nOn display are artifacts, documents, and photographs from throughout the University\u2019s history: books from the first library collection, a course schedule from 1877, panels from early ILLIAC computers, and Olympian Jean Driscoll\u2019s racing chair.\nThe exhibit is accompanied by a series of events for all ages: talks, exhibit tours with the curator, family hands-on activities, and historic campus walking tours. Visit the Museum\u2019s website to learn more http://www.spurlock.illinois.edu/events/#ui150.\nKnowledge at Work runs September 12, 2017\u2013December 21, 2018 and was developed in partnership with the University of Illinois Archives.",
        "Description": "outreach, sesquicentennial",
        "Topics": "No Cost",
        "Contact ": "This exhibition draws from ongoing research into the Nazi-era provenance of KAM\u2019s European painting collection to explore diverse facets of provenance research including genealogy, documentation, the identification of marks and labels, and attribution.",

    {
        "Title": "Exhibition",
        "Event Type": "Sousa Archives and Center for American Music",
        "Sponsor": "Oct 12, 2017 - Sep 3, 2018 \u00a0  All Day ",
        "Location": "No Cost",
        "Date ": "sousa@illinois.edu",
        "Cost": "217-244-9309",
        "E-Mail ": "Library Calendar",
        "Phone ": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nThe University of Illinois Russian Folk Orchestra was founded in 1974 by John Garvey, who had joined the University\u2019s Walden String Quartet in 1948 as its violist and in 1959 established the university\u2019s jazz band program.\u00a0 In 1969, the jazz band toured the Soviet Union as part of the State Department\u2019s cultural exchange program, and Garvey developed a keen interest in Russian folk music.\u00a0 He later returned to the USSR to study Russian folk music traditions and purchased additional folk instruments that he used to establish the Illinois Russian Folk Orchestra.\u00a0 The Illinois ensemble eventually served as a model for other American universities\u2019 Russian folk orchestras by providing open depoliticized educational spaces for students to pursue their interest in Russian folk music traditions.\u00a0 This exhibit of folk instruments, photographs, and music provides visitors with a general introduction to Russian folk music traditions and culture that were promoted by the Soviet Union after the Russian Revolution and the folk musicians who immigrated to the United States after WWII.\u00a0 It also acknowledges many of the talented musicians who performed with the University of Illinois\u2019 Russian Folk Orchestra under Garvey\u2019s direction between 1974 and 1989 and reveals a forgotten part of the University of Illinois\u2019 musical past.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",
        "Views": "Campus General Request Event",
        "Originating Calendar": "The exhibit Knowledge at Work: The University of Illinois at 150 traces the connections between the University of Illinois and people, places, and ideas near and far. Explore this community of educators, researchers, and students over decades of learning, research, and public service. Learn about contributions of a wide variety of people and groups to campus history and ways the University has changed how it relates to the people it serves.\n\u00a0\nFrom its founding as a Land Grant institution in 1867 focused on agriculture and engineering, through expansions into arts, graduate studies, and national and international collaborations, the University has maintained a mission to deliver education and research in service to society. In Knowledge at Work, we look at the role of the University of Illinois as a nexus for bringing together people with diverse backgrounds, perspectives, and experiences in a common pursuit. The background and needs of students and faculty have changed over time, inspiring new facilities, curricula, and services.\nOn display are artifacts, documents, and photographs from throughout the University\u2019s history: books from the first library collection, a course schedule from 1877, panels from early ILLIAC computers, and Olympian Jean Driscoll\u2019s racing chair.\nThe exhibit is accompanied by a series of events for all ages: talks, exhibit tours with the curator, family hands-on activities, and historic campus walking tours. Visit the Museum\u2019s website to learn more http://www.spurlock.illinois.edu/events/#ui150.\nKnowledge at Work runs September 12, 2017\u2013December 21, 2018 and was developed in partnership with the University of Illinois Archives.",

        "Title": "Jun 19, 2018 - Jun 25, 2018 \u00a0  All Day ",
        "Event Type": "Leah Freemon",
        "Sponsor": "lfreemo2@illinois.edu",
        "Location": "Library Calendar",
        "Date ": "129",
        "Cost": "Library Calendar",
        "E-Mail ": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nDuring the late 1960s many university campuses across America experienced significant political and social turmoil.\u00a0 For the University of Illinois the spring of 1970 was a time of tremendous political unrest among students and faculty regarding America\u2019s involvement in the Vietnam war, the US Department of Defense\u2019s construction of the Illiac IV supercomputer on campus, the Champaign-Urbana police force\u2019s killing of an unarmed African American student on the Illinois campus, and the Ohio National Guard\u2019s shooting of four students on the campus of Kent State University. \u00a0\u00a0While Illinois\u2019 students and many of its faculty frequently came together at this time to protest the Federal government\u2019s growing political oppression and imperialism, the campus\u2019 activists and protestors used many different music genres to convey their messages across the Urbana-Champaign campus.\u00a0 Music groups like the Campus Folksong Club, the Walden String Quartet, Medicare 7, 8, or 9, and REO Speedwagon as well as many faculty members from the University\u2019s School of Music frequently lent their musical talents to support these political and social protests. \u00a0This exhibit of photographs, news clippings, advertisements, protest broadsides, concert programs, graphic illustrations, and audio recordings highlight the diverse intersections of music, art, and protest on the Illinois campus during the 1970 school year.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",

    {
        "Title": "217-244-9309",
        "Event Type": "307",
        "Sponsor": "Library Calendar",
        "Location": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nThe Russian imperial capital of St. Petersburg was a major stop during John Philip Sousa\u2019s 1903 tour of Europe.\u00a0 Sousa planned his St. Petersburg performances to coincide with the tsar\u2019s birthday and the bicentennial of the city\u2019s founding, and anticipated large audiences for these concerts because the band had never before played in Russia.\u00a0 What resulted, however, was a misadventure.\u00a0 The concerts occurred at the beginning of Russia\u2019s annual summer vacation when most theaters and concerts halls were closed.\u00a0 In addition Russian music critics\u2019 responses to his music was tepid.\u00a0 Sousa was intimidated by the extensive advertising throughout the city for what he initially believed to be his music rival \u0421\u0443\u0437\u0430, but eventually discovered that this was the Russian spelling of his own name. \u00a0\u00a0While the St. Petersburg performances were not well attended, the concerts did spark deep patriotism among the American diplomats who were able to attend and the Russian aristocracy and military enthusiastically received the Sousa Band\u2019s renditions of the Imperial Russian and American national anthems.\u00a0 This exhibit of photographs, music, newspaper reviews, and political cartoons document Russian perceptions of America and Sousa\u2019s music at the beginning of the twentieth century.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",

        "Location": "ewatkins@illinois.edu",
        "Date ": "217-265-5485",
        "Cost": "399",
        "E-Mail ": "Campus General Request Event",
        "Phone ": "The exhibit Knowledge at Work: The University of Illinois at 150 traces the connections between the University of Illinois and people, places, and ideas near and far. Explore this community of educators, researchers, and students over decades of learning, research, and public service. Learn about contributions of a wide variety of people and groups to campus history and ways the University has changed how it relates to the people it serves.\n\u00a0\nFrom its founding as a Land Grant institution in 1867 focused on agriculture and engineering, through expansions into arts, graduate studies, and national and international collaborations, the University has maintained a mission to deliver education and research in service to society. In Knowledge at Work, we look at the role of the University of Illinois as a nexus for bringing together people with diverse backgrounds, perspectives, and experiences in a common pursuit. The background and needs of students and faculty have changed over time, inspiring new facilities, curricula, and services.\nOn display are artifacts, documents, and photographs from throughout the University\u2019s history: books from the first library collection, a course schedule from 1877, panels from early ILLIAC computers, and Olympian Jean Driscoll\u2019s racing chair.\nThe exhibit is accompanied by a series of events for all ages: talks, exhibit tours with the curator, family hands-on activities, and historic campus walking tours. Visit the Museum\u2019s website to learn more http://www.spurlock.illinois.edu/events/#ui150.\nKnowledge at Work runs September 12, 2017\u2013December 21, 2018 and was developed in partnership with the University of Illinois Archives.",

Explore this community of educators, researchers, and students over decades of learning, research, and public service. Learn about contributions of a wide variety of people and groups to campus history and ways the University has changed how it relates to the people it serves.\n\u00a0\nFrom its founding as a Land Grant institution in 1867 focused on agriculture and engineering, through expansions into arts, graduate studies, and national and international collaborations, the University has maintained a mission to deliver education and research in service to society. In Knowledge at Work, we look at the role of the University of Illinois as a nexus for bringing together people with diverse backgrounds, perspectives, and experiences in a common pursuit. The background and needs of students and faculty have changed over time, inspiring new facilities, curricula, and services.\nOn display are artifacts, documents, and photographs from throughout the University\u2019s history: books from the first library collection, a course schedule from 1877, panels from early ILLIAC computers, and Olympian Jean Driscoll\u2019s racing chair.\nThe exhibit is accompanied by a series of events for all ages: talks, exhibit tours with the curator, family hands-on activities, and historic campus walking tours. Visit the Museum\u2019s website to learn more http://www.spurlock.illinois.edu/events/#ui150.\nKnowledge at Work runs September 12, 2017\u2013December 21, 2018 and was developed in partnership with the University of Illinois Archives.",
        "Views": "\u201cFrom Russia with Love:\u201d John Garvey\u2019s Russian Folk Orchestra",
        "Originating Calendar": "Exhibition",
        "Description": "Sousa Archives and Center for American Music",
        "Topics": "No Cost",
        "Contact ": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nThe University of Illinois Russian Folk Orchestra was founded in 1974 by John Garvey, who had joined the University\u2019s Walden String Quartet in 1948 as its violist and in 1959 established the university\u2019s jazz band program.\u00a0 In 1969, the jazz band toured the Soviet Union as part of the State Department\u2019s cultural exchange program, and Garvey developed a keen interest in Russian folk music.\u00a0 He later returned to the USSR to study Russian folk music traditions and purchased additional folk instruments that he used to establish the Illinois Russian Folk Orchestra.\u00a0 The Illinois ensemble eventually served as a model for other American universities\u2019 Russian folk orchestras by providing open depoliticized educational spaces for students to pursue their interest in Russian folk music traditions.\u00a0 This exhibit of folk instruments, photographs, and music provides visitors with a general introduction to Russian folk music traditions and culture that were promoted by the Soviet Union after the Russian Revolution and the folk musicians who immigrated to the United States after WWII.\u00a0 It also acknowledges many of the talented musicians who performed with the University of Illinois\u2019 Russian Folk Orchestra under Garvey\u2019s direction between 1974 and 1989 and reveals a forgotten part of the University of Illinois\u2019 musical past.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",
        "Topic": "vandvntr@illinois.edu",
        "Registration": "outreach, sesquicentennial",
        "Speaker": "Audubon Plate of the Week: Broad-winged Hawk"
    },

        "Event Type": "Library Calendar",
        "Sponsor": "Sousa and Tsar Nicholas II\u2019s Birthday: An Unexpected Tour Adventure",
        "Location": "Exhibition",
        "Date ": "Sousa Archives and Center for American Music",
        "Cost": "Sousa Archives and Center for American Music, 1103 S. Sixth Street, Champaign",
        "E-Mail ": "Aug 21, 2017 - Aug 6, 2018 \u00a0  All Day ",
        "Phone ": "No Cost",
        "Views": "Jun 22, 2018 \u00a0  All Day ",
        "Originating Calendar": "sousa@illinois.edu",
        "Description": "217-244-9309",
        "Topics": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nThe Russian imperial capital of St. Petersburg was a major stop during John Philip Sousa\u2019s 1903 tour of Europe.\u00a0 Sousa planned his St. Petersburg performances to coincide with the tsar\u2019s birthday and the bicentennial of the city\u2019s founding, and anticipated large audiences for these concerts because the band had never before played in Russia.\u00a0 What resulted, however, was a misadventure.\u00a0 The concerts occurred at the beginning of Russia\u2019s annual summer vacation when most theaters and concerts halls were closed.\u00a0 In addition Russian music critics\u2019 responses to his music was tepid.\u00a0 Sousa was intimidated by the extensive advertising throughout the city for what he initially believed to be his music rival \u0421\u0443\u0437\u0430, but eventually discovered that this was the Russian spelling of his own name. \u00a0\u00a0While the St. Petersburg performances were not well attended, the concerts did spark deep patriotism among the American diplomats who were able to attend and the Russian aristocracy and military enthusiastically received the Sousa Band\u2019s renditions of the Imperial Russian and American national anthems.\u00a0 This exhibit of photographs, music, newspaper reviews, and political cartoons document Russian perceptions of America and Sousa\u2019s music at the beginning of the twentieth century.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",
        "Contact ": "art history, arts, conservation, graduate, medieval studies, provenance, research",
        "Topic": "vandvntr@illinois.edu",
        "Registration": "outreach, sesquicentennial",
        "Speaker": "Audubon Plate of the Week: Broad-winged Hawk"

        "Title": "free",
        "Event Type": "Beth Watkins",
        "Sponsor": "ewatkins@illinois.edu",
        "Location": "217-265-5485",
        "Date ": "399",
        "Cost": "Campus General Request Event",
        "E-Mail ": "The exhibit Knowledge at Work: The University of Illinois at 150 traces the connections between the University of Illinois and people, places, and ideas near and far. Explore this community of educators, researchers, and students over decades of learning, research, and public service. Learn about contributions of a wide variety of people and groups to campus history and ways the University has changed how it relates to the people it serves.\n\u00a0\nFrom its founding as a Land Grant institution in 1867 focused on agriculture and engineering, through expansions into arts, graduate studies, and national and international collaborations, the University has maintained a mission to deliver education and research in service to society. In Knowledge at Work, we look at the role of the University of Illinois as a nexus for bringing together people with diverse backgrounds, perspectives, and experiences in a common pursuit. The background and needs of students and faculty have changed over time, inspiring new facilities, curricula, and services.\nOn display are artifacts, documents, and photographs from throughout the University\u2019s history: books from the first library collection, a course schedule from 1877, panels from early ILLIAC computers, and Olympian Jean Driscoll\u2019s racing chair.\nThe exhibit is accompanied by a series of events for all ages: talks, exhibit tours with the curator, family hands-on activities, and historic campus walking tours. Visit the Museum\u2019s website to learn more http://www.spurlock.illinois.edu/events/#ui150.\nKnowledge at Work runs September 12, 2017\u2013December 21, 2018 and was developed in partnership with the University of Illinois Archives.",

        "Views": "Jun 22, 2018 \u00a0  All Day ",

        "Topics": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nThe Russian imperial capital of St. Petersburg was a major stop during John Philip Sousa\u2019s 1903 tour of Europe.\u00a0 Sousa planned his St. Petersburg performances to coincide with the tsar\u2019s birthday and the bicentennial of the city\u2019s founding, and anticipated large audiences for these concerts because the band had never before played in Russia.\u00a0 What resulted, however, was a misadventure.\u00a0 The concerts occurred at the beginning of Russia\u2019s annual summer vacation when most theaters and concerts halls were closed.\u00a0 In addition Russian music critics\u2019 responses to his music was tepid.\u00a0 Sousa was intimidated by the extensive advertising throughout the city for what he initially believed to be his music rival \u0421\u0443\u0437\u0430, but eventually discovered that this was the Russian spelling of his own name. \u00a0\u00a0While the St. Petersburg performances were not well attended, the concerts did spark deep patriotism among the American diplomats who were able to attend and the Russian aristocracy and military enthusiastically received the Sousa Band\u2019s renditions of the Imperial Russian and American national anthems.\u00a0 This exhibit of photographs, music, newspaper reviews, and political cartoons document Russian perceptions of America and Sousa\u2019s music at the beginning of the twentieth century.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",

    {
        "Title": "Oct 12, 2017 - Sep 3, 2018 \u00a0  All Day ",
        "Event Type": "No Cost",
        "Sponsor": "217-244-9309",
        "Location": "200",
        "Date ": "Library Calendar",
        "Cost": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nThe University of Illinois Russian Folk Orchestra was founded in 1974 by John Garvey, who had joined the University\u2019s Walden String Quartet in 1948 as its violist and in 1959 established the university\u2019s jazz band program.\u00a0 In 1969, the jazz band toured the Soviet Union as part of the State Department\u2019s cultural exchange program, and Garvey developed a keen interest in Russian folk music.\u00a0 He later returned to the USSR to study Russian folk music traditions and purchased additional folk instruments that he used to establish the Illinois Russian Folk Orchestra.\u00a0 The Illinois ensemble eventually served as a model for other American universities\u2019 Russian folk orchestras by providing open depoliticized educational spaces for students to pursue their interest in Russian folk music traditions.\u00a0 This exhibit of folk instruments, photographs, and music provides visitors with a general introduction to Russian folk music traditions and culture that were promoted by the Soviet Union after the Russian Revolution and the folk musicians who immigrated to the United States after WWII.\u00a0 It also acknowledges many of the talented musicians who performed with the University of Illinois\u2019 Russian Folk Orchestra under Garvey\u2019s direction between 1974 and 1989 and reveals a forgotten part of the University of Illinois\u2019 musical past.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",
        "E-Mail ": "The exhibit Knowledge at Work: The University of Illinois at 150 traces the connections between the University of Illinois and people, places, and ideas near and far. Explore this community of educators, researchers, and students over decades of learning, research, and public service. Learn about contributions of a wide variety of people and groups to campus history and ways the University has changed how it relates to the people it serves.\n\u00a0\nFrom its founding as a Land Grant institution in 1867 focused on agriculture and engineering, through expansions into arts, graduate studies, and national and international collaborations, the University has maintained a mission to deliver education and research in service to society. In Knowledge at Work, we look at the role of the University of Illinois as a nexus for bringing together people with diverse backgrounds, perspectives, and experiences in a common pursuit. The background and needs of students and faculty have changed over time, inspiring new facilities, curricula, and services.\nOn display are artifacts, documents, and photographs from throughout the University\u2019s history: books from the first library collection, a course schedule from 1877, panels from early ILLIAC computers, and Olympian Jean Driscoll\u2019s racing chair.\nThe exhibit is accompanied by a series of events for all ages: talks, exhibit tours with the curator, family hands-on activities, and historic campus walking tours. Visit the Museum\u2019s website to learn more http://www.spurlock.illinois.edu/events/#ui150.\nKnowledge at Work runs September 12, 2017\u2013December 21, 2018 and was developed in partnership with the University of Illinois Archives.",

        "Title": "sousa@illinois.edu",
        "Event Type": "217-244-9309",
        "Sponsor": "129",
        "Location": "Library Calendar",
        "Date ": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nDuring the late 1960s many university campuses across America experienced significant political and social turmoil.\u00a0 For the University of Illinois the spring of 1970 was a time of tremendous political unrest among students and faculty regarding America\u2019s involvement in the Vietnam war, the US Department of Defense\u2019s construction of the Illiac IV supercomputer on campus, the Champaign-Urbana police force\u2019s killing of an unarmed African American student on the Illinois campus, and the Ohio National Guard\u2019s shooting of four students on the campus of Kent State University. \u00a0\u00a0While Illinois\u2019 students and many of its faculty frequently came together at this time to protest the Federal government\u2019s growing political oppression and imperialism, the campus\u2019 activists and protestors used many different music genres to convey their messages across the Urbana-Champaign campus.\u00a0 Music groups like the Campus Folksong Club, the Walden String Quartet, Medicare 7, 8, or 9, and REO Speedwagon as well as many faculty members from the University\u2019s School of Music frequently lent their musical talents to support these political and social protests. \u00a0This exhibit of photographs, news clippings, advertisements, protest broadsides, concert programs, graphic illustrations, and audio recordings highlight the diverse intersections of music, art, and protest on the Illinois campus during the 1970 school year.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",
        "Cost": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nThe University of Illinois Russian Folk Orchestra was founded in 1974 by John Garvey, who had joined the University\u2019s Walden String Quartet in 1948 as its violist and in 1959 established the university\u2019s jazz band program.\u00a0 In 1969, the jazz band toured the Soviet Union as part of the State Department\u2019s cultural exchange program, and Garvey developed a keen interest in Russian folk music.\u00a0 He later returned to the USSR to study Russian folk music traditions and purchased additional folk instruments that he used to establish the Illinois Russian Folk Orchestra.\u00a0 The Illinois ensemble eventually served as a model for other American universities\u2019 Russian folk orchestras by providing open depoliticized educational spaces for students to pursue their interest in Russian folk music traditions.\u00a0 This exhibit of folk instruments, photographs, and music provides visitors with a general introduction to Russian folk music traditions and culture that were promoted by the Soviet Union after the Russian Revolution and the folk musicians who immigrated to the United States after WWII.\u00a0 It also acknowledges many of the talented musicians who performed with the University of Illinois\u2019 Russian Folk Orchestra under Garvey\u2019s direction between 1974 and 1989 and reveals a forgotten part of the University of Illinois\u2019 musical past.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",
        "E-Mail ": "Exhibition",
        "Phone ": "Sousa Archives and Center for American Music",
        "Views": "Sousa Archives and Center for American Music, 1103 S. Sixth Street, Champaign",

        "Date ": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nDuring the late 1960s many university campuses across America experienced significant political and social turmoil.\u00a0 For the University of Illinois the spring of 1970 was a time of tremendous political unrest among students and faculty regarding America\u2019s involvement in the Vietnam war, the US Department of Defense\u2019s construction of the Illiac IV supercomputer on campus, the Champaign-Urbana police force\u2019s killing of an unarmed African American student on the Illinois campus, and the Ohio National Guard\u2019s shooting of four students on the campus of Kent State University. \u00a0\u00a0While Illinois\u2019 students and many of its faculty frequently came together at this time to protest the Federal government\u2019s growing political oppression and imperialism, the campus\u2019 activists and protestors used many different music genres to convey their messages across the Urbana-Champaign campus.\u00a0 Music groups like the Campus Folksong Club, the Walden String Quartet, Medicare 7, 8, or 9, and REO Speedwagon as well as many faculty members from the University\u2019s School of Music frequently lent their musical talents to support these political and social protests. \u00a0This exhibit of photographs, news clippings, advertisements, protest broadsides, concert programs, graphic illustrations, and audio recordings highlight the diverse intersections of music, art, and protest on the Illinois campus during the 1970 school year.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",

        "Cost": "The exhibit Knowledge at Work: The University of Illinois at 150 traces the connections between the University of Illinois and people, places, and ideas near and far. Explore this community of educators, researchers, and students over decades of learning, research, and public service. Learn about contributions of a wide variety of people and groups to campus history and ways the University has changed how it relates to the people it serves.\n\u00a0\nFrom its founding as a Land Grant institution in 1867 focused on agriculture and engineering, through expansions into arts, graduate studies, and national and international collaborations, the University has maintained a mission to deliver education and research in service to society. In Knowledge at Work, we look at the role of the University of Illinois as a nexus for bringing together people with diverse backgrounds, perspectives, and experiences in a common pursuit. The background and needs of students and faculty have changed over time, inspiring new facilities, curricula, and services.\nOn display are artifacts, documents, and photographs from throughout the University\u2019s history: books from the first library collection, a course schedule from 1877, panels from early ILLIAC computers, and Olympian Jean Driscoll\u2019s racing chair.\nThe exhibit is accompanied by a series of events for all ages: talks, exhibit tours with the curator, family hands-on activities, and historic campus walking tours.         "Event Type": "129",
        "Sponsor": "Library Calendar",
        "Location": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nDuring the late 1960s many university campuses across America experienced significant political and social turmoil.\u00a0 For the University of Illinois the spring of 1970 was a time of tremendous political unrest among students and faculty regarding America\u2019s involvement in the Vietnam war, the US Department of Defense\u2019s construction of the Illiac IV supercomputer on campus, the Champaign-Urbana police force\u2019s killing of an unarmed African American student on the Illinois campus, and the Ohio National Guard\u2019s shooting of four students on the campus of Kent State University. \u00a0\u00a0While Illinois\u2019 students and many of its faculty frequently came together at this time to protest the Federal government\u2019s growing political oppression and imperialism, the campus\u2019 activists and protestors used many different music genres to convey their messages across the Urbana-Champaign campus.\u00a0 Music groups like the Campus Folksong Club, the Walden String Quartet, Medicare 7, 8, or 9, and REO Speedwagon as well as many faculty members from the University\u2019s School of Music frequently lent their musical talents to support these political and social protests. \u00a0This exhibit of photographs, news clippings, advertisements, protest broadsides, concert programs, graphic illustrations, and audio recordings highlight the diverse intersections of music, art, and protest on the Illinois campus during the 1970 school year.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",
        "Date ": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nThe University of Illinois Russian Folk Orchestra was founded in 1974 by John Garvey, who had joined the University\u2019s Walden String Quartet in 1948 as its violist and in 1959 established the university\u2019s jazz band program.\u00a0 In 1969, the jazz band toured the Soviet Union as part of the State Department\u2019s cultural exchange program, and Garvey developed a keen interest in Russian folk music.\u00a0 He later returned to the USSR to study Russian folk music traditions and purchased additional folk instruments that he used to establish the Illinois Russian Folk Orchestra.\u00a0 The Illinois ensemble eventually served as a model for other American universities\u2019 Russian folk orchestras by providing open depoliticized educational spaces for students to pursue their interest in Russian folk music traditions.\u00a0 This exhibit of folk instruments, photographs, and music provides visitors with a general introduction to Russian folk music traditions and culture that were promoted by the Soviet Union after the Russian Revolution and the folk musicians who immigrated to the United States after WWII.\u00a0 It also acknowledges many of the talented musicians who performed with the University of Illinois\u2019 Russian Folk Orchestra under Garvey\u2019s direction between 1974 and 1989 and reveals a forgotten part of the University of Illinois\u2019 musical past.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",
        "Cost": "Illinois\u2019 Anti-Establishment Soundscapes: Troubled Waters in 1970",
        "E-Mail ": "Sousa Archives and Center for American Music",
        "Phone ": "Sousa Archives and Center for American Music, 1103 S. Sixth Street, Champaign",
        "Views": "Oct 30, 2017 - Oct 29, 2018 \u00a0  All Day ",

        "Topic": "This exhibition draws from ongoing research into the Nazi-era provenance of KAM\u2019s European painting collection to explore diverse facets of provenance research including genealogy, documentation, the identification of marks and labels, and attribution.",

        "Location": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nDuring the late 1960s many university campuses across America experienced significant political and social turmoil.\u00a0 For the University of Illinois the spring of 1970 was a time of tremendous political unrest among students and faculty regarding America\u2019s involvement in the Vietnam war, the US Department of Defense\u2019s construction of the Illiac IV supercomputer on campus, the Champaign-Urbana police force\u2019s killing of an unarmed African American student on the Illinois campus, and the Ohio National Guard\u2019s shooting of four students on the campus of Kent State University. \u00a0\u00a0While Illinois\u2019 students and many of its faculty frequently came together at this time to protest the Federal government\u2019s growing political oppression and imperialism, the campus\u2019 activists and protestors used many different music genres to convey their messages across the Urbana-Champaign campus.\u00a0 Music groups like the Campus Folksong Club, the Walden String Quartet, Medicare 7, 8, or 9, and REO Speedwagon as well as many faculty members from the University\u2019s School of Music frequently lent their musical talents to support these political and social protests. \u00a0This exhibit of photographs, news clippings, advertisements, protest broadsides, concert programs, graphic illustrations, and audio recordings highlight the diverse intersections of music, art, and protest on the Illinois campus during the 1970 school year.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",

    {
        "Title": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nThe Russian imperial capital of St. Petersburg was a major stop during John Philip Sousa\u2019s 1903 tour of Europe.\u00a0 Sousa planned his St. Petersburg performances to coincide with the tsar\u2019s birthday and the bicentennial of the city\u2019s founding, and anticipated large audiences for these concerts because the band had never before played in Russia.\u00a0 What resulted, however, was a misadventure.\u00a0 The concerts occurred at the beginning of Russia\u2019s annual summer vacation when most theaters and concerts halls were closed.\u00a0 In addition Russian music critics\u2019 responses to his music was tepid.\u00a0 Sousa was intimidated by the extensive advertising throughout the city for what he initially believed to be his music rival \u0421\u0443\u0437\u0430, but eventually discovered that this was the Russian spelling of his own name. \u00a0\u00a0While the St. Petersburg performances were not well attended, the concerts did spark deep patriotism among the American diplomats who were able to attend and the Russian aristocracy and military enthusiastically received the Sousa Band\u2019s renditions of the Imperial Russian and American national anthems.\u00a0 This exhibit of photographs, music, newspaper reviews, and political cartoons document Russian perceptions of America and Sousa\u2019s music at the beginning of the twentieth century.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",
        "Event Type": "Sousa and Tsar Nicholas II\u2019s Birthday: An Unexpected Tour Adventure",
        "Sponsor": "Exhibition",
        "Location": "Sousa Archives and Center for American Music",
        "Date ": "Sousa Archives and Center for American Music, 1103 S. Sixth Street, Champaign",

        "Title": "ewatkins@illinois.edu",
        "Event Type": "217-265-5485",
        "Sponsor": "399",
        "Location": "Campus General Request Event",
        "Date ": "The exhibit Knowledge at Work: The University of Illinois at 150 traces the connections between the University of Illinois and people, places, and ideas near and far. Explore this community of educators, researchers, and students over decades of learning, research, and public service. Learn about contributions of a wide variety of people and groups to campus history and ways the University has changed how it relates to the people it serves.\n\u00a0\nFrom its founding as a Land Grant institution in 1867 focused on agriculture and engineering, through expansions into arts, graduate studies, and national and international collaborations, the University has maintained a mission to deliver education and research in service to society. In Knowledge at Work, we look at the role of the University of Illinois as a nexus for bringing together people with diverse backgrounds, perspectives, and experiences in a common pursuit. The background and needs of students and faculty have changed over time, inspiring new facilities, curricula, and services.\nOn display are artifacts, documents, and photographs from throughout the University\u2019s history: books from the first library collection, a course schedule from 1877, panels from early ILLIAC computers, and Olympian Jean Driscoll\u2019s racing chair.\nThe exhibit is accompanied by a series of events for all ages: talks, exhibit tours with the curator, family hands-on activities, and historic campus walking tours. Visit the Museum\u2019s website to learn more http://www.spurlock.illinois.edu/events/#ui150.\nKnowledge at Work runs September 12, 2017\u2013December 21, 2018 and was developed in partnership with the University of Illinois Archives.",
        "Cost": "Aug 21, 2017 - Aug 6, 2018 \u00a0  All Day ",
        "E-Mail ": "Sep 12, 2017 - Aug 15, 2018 \u00a0  All Day ",

        "Title": "sousa@illinois.edu",
        "Event Type": "217-244-9309",
        "Sponsor": "Library Calendar",
        "Location": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nThe University of Illinois Russian Folk Orchestra was founded in 1974 by John Garvey, who had joined the University\u2019s Walden String Quartet in 1948 as its violist and in 1959 established the university\u2019s jazz band program.\u00a0 In 1969, the jazz band toured the Soviet Union as part of the State Department\u2019s cultural exchange program, and Garvey developed a keen interest in Russian folk music.\u00a0 He later returned to the USSR to study Russian folk music traditions and purchased additional folk instruments that he used to establish the Illinois Russian Folk Orchestra.\u00a0 The Illinois ensemble eventually served as a model for other American universities\u2019 Russian folk orchestras by providing open depoliticized educational spaces for students to pursue their interest in Russian folk music traditions.\u00a0 This exhibit of folk instruments, photographs, and music provides visitors with a general introduction to Russian folk music traditions and culture that were promoted by the Soviet Union after the Russian Revolution and the folk musicians who immigrated to the United States after WWII.\u00a0 It also acknowledges many of the talented musicians who performed with the University of Illinois\u2019 Russian Folk Orchestra under Garvey\u2019s direction between 1974 and 1989 and reveals a forgotten part of the University of Illinois\u2019 musical past.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",
        "Date ": "The exhibit Knowledge at Work: The University of Illinois at 150 traces the connections between the University of Illinois and people, places, and ideas near and far. Explore this community of educators, researchers, and students over decades of learning, research, and public service. Learn about contributions of a wide variety of people and groups to campus history and ways the University has changed how it relates to the people it serves.\n\u00a0\nFrom its founding as a Land Grant institution in 1867 focused on agriculture and engineering, through expansions into arts, graduate studies, and national and international collaborations, the University has maintained a mission to deliver education and research in service to society. In Knowledge at Work, we look at the role of the University of Illinois as a nexus for bringing together people with diverse backgrounds, perspectives, and experiences in a common pursuit. The background and needs of students and faculty have changed over time, inspiring new facilities, curricula, and services.\nOn display are artifacts, documents, and photographs from throughout the University\u2019s history: books from the first library collection, a course schedule from 1877, panels from early ILLIAC computers, and Olympian Jean Driscoll\u2019s racing chair.\nThe exhibit is accompanied by a series of events for all ages: talks, exhibit tours with the curator, family hands-on activities, and historic campus walking tours. Visit the Museum\u2019s website to learn more http://www.spurlock.illinois.edu/events/#ui150.\nKnowledge at Work runs September 12, 2017\u2013December 21, 2018 and was developed in partnership with the University of Illinois Archives.",

        "Sponsor": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nThe University of Illinois Russian Folk Orchestra was founded in 1974 by John Garvey, who had joined the University\u2019s Walden String Quartet in 1948 as its violist and in 1959 established the university\u2019s jazz band program.\u00a0 In 1969, the jazz band toured the Soviet Union as part of the State Department\u2019s cultural exchange program, and Garvey developed a keen interest in Russian folk music.\u00a0 He later returned to the USSR to study Russian folk music traditions and purchased additional folk instruments that he used to establish the Illinois Russian Folk Orchestra.\u00a0 The Illinois ensemble eventually served as a model for other American universities\u2019 Russian folk orchestras by providing open depoliticized educational spaces for students to pursue their interest in Russian folk music traditions.\u00a0 This exhibit of folk instruments, photographs, and music provides visitors with a general introduction to Russian folk music traditions and culture that were promoted by the Soviet Union after the Russian Revolution and the folk musicians who immigrated to the United States after WWII.\u00a0 It also acknowledges many of the talented musicians who performed with the University of Illinois\u2019 Russian Folk Orchestra under Garvey\u2019s direction between 1974 and 1989 and reveals a forgotten part of the University of Illinois\u2019 musical past.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",
        "Location": "The exhibit Knowledge at Work: The University of Illinois at 150 traces the connections between the University of Illinois and people, places, and ideas near and far. Explore this community of educators, researchers, and students over decades of learning, research, and public service. Learn about contributions of a wide variety of people and groups to campus history and ways the University has changed how it relates to the people it serves.\n\u00a0\nFrom its founding as a Land Grant institution in 1867 focused on agriculture and engineering, through expansions into arts, graduate studies, and national and international collaborations, the University has maintained a mission to deliver education and research in service to society. In Knowledge at Work, we look at the role of the University of Illinois as a nexus for bringing together people with diverse backgrounds, perspectives, and experiences in a common pursuit. The background and needs of students and faculty have changed over time, inspiring new facilities, curricula, and services.\nOn display are artifacts, documents, and photographs from throughout the University\u2019s history: books from the first library collection, a course schedule from 1877, panels from early ILLIAC computers, and Olympian Jean Driscoll\u2019s racing chair.\nThe exhibit is accompanied by a series of events for all ages: talks, exhibit tours with the curator, family hands-on activities, and historic campus walking tours. Visit the Museum\u2019s website to learn more http://www.spurlock.illinois.edu/events/#ui150.\nKnowledge at Work runs September 12, 2017\u2013December 21, 2018 and was developed in partnership with the University of Illinois Archives.",
        "Date ": "\u201cFrom Russia with Love:\u201d John Garvey\u2019s Russian Folk Orchestra",

    {
        "Title": "Library Calendar",
        "Event Type": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nDuring the late 1960s many university campuses across America experienced significant political and social turmoil.\u00a0 For the University of Illinois the spring of 1970 was a time of tremendous political unrest among students and faculty regarding America\u2019s involvement in the Vietnam war, the US Department of Defense\u2019s construction of the Illiac IV supercomputer on campus, the Champaign-Urbana police force\u2019s killing of an unarmed African American student on the Illinois campus, and the Ohio National Guard\u2019s shooting of four students on the campus of Kent State University. \u00a0\u00a0While Illinois\u2019 students and many of its faculty frequently came together at this time to protest the Federal government\u2019s growing political oppression and imperialism, the campus\u2019 activists and protestors used many different music genres to convey their messages across the Urbana-Champaign campus.\u00a0 Music groups like the Campus Folksong Club, the Walden String Quartet, Medicare 7, 8, or 9, and REO Speedwagon as well as many faculty members from the University\u2019s School of Music frequently lent their musical talents to support these political and social protests. \u00a0This exhibit of photographs, news clippings, advertisements, protest broadsides, concert programs, graphic illustrations, and audio recordings highlight the diverse intersections of music, art, and protest on the Illinois campus during the 1970 school year.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",
        "Sponsor": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nThe University of Illinois Russian Folk Orchestra was founded in 1974 by John Garvey, who had joined the University\u2019s Walden String Quartet in 1948 as its violist and in 1959 established the university\u2019s jazz band program.\u00a0 In 1969, the jazz band toured the Soviet Union as part of the State Department\u2019s cultural exchange program, and Garvey developed a keen interest in Russian folk music.\u00a0 He later returned to the USSR to study Russian folk music traditions and purchased additional folk instruments that he used to establish the Illinois Russian Folk Orchestra.\u00a0 The Illinois ensemble eventually served as a model for other American universities\u2019 Russian folk orchestras by providing open depoliticized educational spaces for students to pursue their interest in Russian folk music traditions.\u00a0 This exhibit of folk instruments, photographs, and music provides visitors with a general introduction to Russian folk music traditions and culture that were promoted by the Soviet Union after the Russian Revolution and the folk musicians who immigrated to the United States after WWII.\u00a0 It also acknowledges many of the talented musicians who performed with the University of Illinois\u2019 Russian Folk Orchestra under Garvey\u2019s direction between 1974 and 1989 and reveals a forgotten part of the University of Illinois\u2019 musical past.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",
        "Location": "Illinois\u2019 Anti-Establishment Soundscapes: Troubled Waters in 1970",

    {
        "Title": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nThe Russian imperial capital of St. Petersburg was a major stop during John Philip Sousa\u2019s 1903 tour of Europe.\u00a0 Sousa planned his St. Petersburg performances to coincide with the tsar\u2019s birthday and the bicentennial of the city\u2019s founding, and anticipated large audiences for these concerts because the band had never before played in Russia.\u00a0 What resulted, however, was a misadventure.\u00a0 The concerts occurred at the beginning of Russia\u2019s annual summer vacation when most theaters and concerts halls were closed.\u00a0 In addition Russian music critics\u2019 responses to his music was tepid.\u00a0 Sousa was intimidated by the extensive advertising throughout the city for what he initially believed to be his music rival \u0421\u0443\u0437\u0430, but eventually discovered that this was the Russian spelling of his own name. \u00a0\u00a0While the St. Petersburg performances were not well attended, the concerts did spark deep patriotism among the American diplomats who were able to attend and the Russian aristocracy and military enthusiastically received the Sousa Band\u2019s renditions of the Imperial Russian and American national anthems.\u00a0 This exhibit of photographs, music, newspaper reviews, and political cartoons document Russian perceptions of America and Sousa\u2019s music at the beginning of the twentieth century.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",
        "Event Type": "Sousa and Tsar Nicholas II\u2019s Birthday: An Unexpected Tour Adventure",
        "Sponsor": "Sousa Archives and Center for American Music",
        "Location": "Sousa Archives and Center for American Music, 1103 S. Sixth Street, Champaign",
        "Date ": "Aug 21, 2017 - Aug 6, 2018 \u00a0  All Day ",

        "Sponsor": "The exhibit Knowledge at Work: The University of Illinois at 150 traces the connections between the University of Illinois and people, places, and ideas near and far. Explore this community of educators, researchers, and students over decades of learning, research, and public service. Learn about contributions of a wide variety of people and groups to campus history and ways the University has changed how it relates to the people it serves.\n\u00a0\nFrom its founding as a Land Grant institution in 1867 focused on agriculture and engineering, through expansions into arts, graduate studies, and national and international collaborations, the University has maintained a mission to deliver education and research in service to society. In Knowledge at Work, we look at the role of the University of Illinois as a nexus for bringing together people with diverse backgrounds, perspectives, and experiences in a common pursuit. The background and needs of students and faculty have changed over time, inspiring new facilities, curricula, and services.\nOn display are artifacts, documents, and photographs from throughout the University\u2019s history: books from the first library collection, a course schedule from 1877, panels from early ILLIAC computers, and Olympian Jean Driscoll\u2019s racing chair.\nThe exhibit is accompanied by a series of events for all ages: talks, exhibit tours with the curator, family hands-on activities, and historic campus walking tours.         "Topics": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nThe University of Illinois Russian Folk Orchestra was founded in 1974 by John Garvey, who had joined the University\u2019s Walden String Quartet in 1948 as its violist and in 1959 established the university\u2019s jazz band program.\u00a0 In 1969, the jazz band toured the Soviet Union as part of the State Department\u2019s cultural exchange program, and Garvey developed a keen interest in Russian folk music.\u00a0 He later returned to the USSR to study Russian folk music traditions and purchased additional folk instruments that he used to establish the Illinois Russian Folk Orchestra.\u00a0 The Illinois ensemble eventually served as a model for other American universities\u2019 Russian folk orchestras by providing open depoliticized educational spaces for students to pursue their interest in Russian folk music traditions.\u00a0 This exhibit of folk instruments, photographs, and music provides visitors with a general introduction to Russian folk music traditions and culture that were promoted by the Soviet Union after the Russian Revolution and the folk musicians who immigrated to the United States after WWII.\u00a0 It also acknowledges many of the talented musicians who performed with the University of Illinois\u2019 Russian Folk Orchestra under Garvey\u2019s direction between 1974 and 1989 and reveals a forgotten part of the University of Illinois\u2019 musical past.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",
        "Contact ": "kam@illinois.edu",
        "Topic": "This exhibition draws from ongoing research into the Nazi-era provenance of KAM\u2019s European painting collection to explore diverse facets of provenance research including genealogy, documentation, the identification of marks and labels, and attribution.",

        "Phone ": "Join us for a traditional Japanese tea ceremony. Chado, or the Way of Tea, is one of the most ancient and revered arts of Japan, and is at the very heart of Japan House. Learn the history behind this art, and enjoy a bowl of matcha tea and a traditional sweet. Experience a moment of peace.\nReservations are required. You will be asked to remove your shoes (or use shoe covers) when you enter, and to wear white socks (we have some to lend you if you forget). We also ask that legs be covered as is traditional in Japan. You will be kneeling or sitting on the tatami mats, but if that is a problem we can easily pull a chair up to the tea room for you, and you still still be at the same height as the other participants.",

        "E-Mail ": "Library Calendar",
        "Phone ": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nThe Russian imperial capital of St. Petersburg was a major stop during John Philip Sousa\u2019s 1903 tour of Europe.\u00a0 Sousa planned his St. Petersburg performances to coincide with the tsar\u2019s birthday and the bicentennial of the city\u2019s founding, and anticipated large audiences for these concerts because the band had never before played in Russia.\u00a0 What resulted, however, was a misadventure.\u00a0 The concerts occurred at the beginning of Russia\u2019s annual summer vacation when most theaters and concerts halls were closed.\u00a0 In addition Russian music critics\u2019 responses to his music was tepid.\u00a0 Sousa was intimidated by the extensive advertising throughout the city for what he initially believed to be his music rival \u0421\u0443\u0437\u0430, but eventually discovered that this was the Russian spelling of his own name. \u00a0\u00a0While the St. Petersburg performances were not well attended, the concerts did spark deep patriotism among the American diplomats who were able to attend and the Russian aristocracy and military enthusiastically received the Sousa Band\u2019s renditions of the Imperial Russian and American national anthems.\u00a0 This exhibit of photographs, music, newspaper reviews, and political cartoons document Russian perceptions of America and Sousa\u2019s music at the beginning of the twentieth century.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",
        "Views": "This exhibition draws from ongoing research into the Nazi-era provenance of KAM\u2019s European painting collection to explore diverse facets of provenance research including genealogy, documentation, the identification of marks and labels, and attribution.",

        "Title": "Campus General Request Event",
        "Event Type": "The exhibit Knowledge at Work: The University of Illinois at 150 traces the connections between the University of Illinois and people, places, and ideas near and far. Explore this community of educators, researchers, and students over decades of learning, research, and public service. Learn about contributions of a wide variety of people and groups to campus history and ways the University has changed how it relates to the people it serves.\n\u00a0\nFrom its founding as a Land Grant institution in 1867 focused on agriculture and engineering, through expansions into arts, graduate studies, and national and international collaborations, the University has maintained a mission to deliver education and research in service to society. In Knowledge at Work, we look at the role of the University of Illinois as a nexus for bringing together people with diverse backgrounds, perspectives, and experiences in a common pursuit. The background and needs of students and faculty have changed over time, inspiring new facilities, curricula, and services.\nOn display are artifacts, documents, and photographs from throughout the University\u2019s history: books from the first library collection, a course schedule from 1877, panels from early ILLIAC computers, and Olympian Jean Driscoll\u2019s racing chair.\nThe exhibit is accompanied by a series of events for all ages: talks, exhibit tours with the curator, family hands-on activities, and historic campus walking tours. Visit the Museum\u2019s website to learn more http://www.spurlock.illinois.edu/events/#ui150.\nKnowledge at Work runs September 12, 2017\u2013December 21, 2018 and was developed in partnership with the University of Illinois Archives.",

        "Phone ": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nThe Russian imperial capital of St. Petersburg was a major stop during John Philip Sousa\u2019s 1903 tour of Europe.\u00a0 Sousa planned his St. Petersburg performances to coincide with the tsar\u2019s birthday and the bicentennial of the city\u2019s founding, and anticipated large audiences for these concerts because the band had never before played in Russia.\u00a0 What resulted, however, was a misadventure.\u00a0 The concerts occurred at the beginning of Russia\u2019s annual summer vacation when most theaters and concerts halls were closed.\u00a0 In addition Russian music critics\u2019 responses to his music was tepid.\u00a0 Sousa was intimidated by the extensive advertising throughout the city for what he initially believed to be his music rival \u0421\u0443\u0437\u0430, but eventually discovered that this was the Russian spelling of his own name. \u00a0\u00a0While the St. Petersburg performances were not well attended, the concerts did spark deep patriotism among the American diplomats who were able to attend and the Russian aristocracy and military enthusiastically received the Sousa Band\u2019s renditions of the Imperial Russian and American national anthems.\u00a0 This exhibit of photographs, music, newspaper reviews, and political cartoons document Russian perceptions of America and Sousa\u2019s music at the beginning of the twentieth century.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",

        "Event Type": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nThe University of Illinois Russian Folk Orchestra was founded in 1974 by John Garvey, who had joined the University\u2019s Walden String Quartet in 1948 as its violist and in 1959 established the university\u2019s jazz band program.\u00a0 In 1969, the jazz band toured the Soviet Union as part of the State Department\u2019s cultural exchange program, and Garvey developed a keen interest in Russian folk music.\u00a0 He later returned to the USSR to study Russian folk music traditions and purchased additional folk instruments that he used to establish the Illinois Russian Folk Orchestra.\u00a0 The Illinois ensemble eventually served as a model for other American universities\u2019 Russian folk orchestras by providing open depoliticized educational spaces for students to pursue their interest in Russian folk music traditions.\u00a0 This exhibit of folk instruments, photographs, and music provides visitors with a general introduction to Russian folk music traditions and culture that were promoted by the Soviet Union after the Russian Revolution and the folk musicians who immigrated to the United States after WWII.\u00a0 It also acknowledges many of the talented musicians who performed with the University of Illinois\u2019 Russian Folk Orchestra under Garvey\u2019s direction between 1974 and 1989 and reveals a forgotten part of the University of Illinois\u2019 musical past.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",
        "Sponsor": "Exhibition",
        "Location": "Sousa Archives and Center for American Music",

        "Views": "129",
        "Originating Calendar": "Library Calendar",
        "Description": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nDuring the late 1960s many university campuses across America experienced significant political and social turmoil.\u00a0 For the University of Illinois the spring of 1970 was a time of tremendous political unrest among students and faculty regarding America\u2019s involvement in the Vietnam war, the US Department of Defense\u2019s construction of the Illiac IV supercomputer on campus, the Champaign-Urbana police force\u2019s killing of an unarmed African American student on the Illinois campus, and the Ohio National Guard\u2019s shooting of four students on the campus of Kent State University. \u00a0\u00a0While Illinois\u2019 students and many of its faculty frequently came together at this time to protest the Federal government\u2019s growing political oppression and imperialism, the campus\u2019 activists and protestors used many different music genres to convey their messages across the Urbana-Champaign campus.\u00a0 Music groups like the Campus Folksong Club, the Walden String Quartet, Medicare 7, 8, or 9, and REO Speedwagon as well as many faculty members from the University\u2019s School of Music frequently lent their musical talents to support these political and social protests. \u00a0This exhibit of photographs, news clippings, advertisements, protest broadsides, concert programs, graphic illustrations, and audio recordings highlight the diverse intersections of music, art, and protest on the Illinois campus during the 1970 school year.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",
        "Topics": "Illinois\u2019 Anti-Establishment Soundscapes: Troubled Waters in 1970",

        "Title": "College of Education Events",
        "Event Type": "Children\u2019s language use grows dramatically throughout the toddler and preschool years. Words and phrases expand daily and children begin to form sentences that go beyond sharing their preferences. Their speech sounds continue to develop and include both predictable, and sometimes adorable, error patterns. Pre-literacy skills also emerge during this developmental window and lay the foundation for academic success as children approach elementary school. In this webinar, the presenters will discuss decontextualized language, early developing morphemes, timelines for phonological processes, and preliteracy achievements during the preschool years, as well as when to worry that a child's speech and language doesn't seem to be progressing as expected.",

        "Title": "The exhibit Knowledge at Work: The University of Illinois at 150 traces the connections between the University of Illinois and people, places, and ideas near and far. Explore this community of educators, researchers, and students over decades of learning, research, and public service. Learn about contributions of a wide variety of people and groups to campus history and ways the University has changed how it relates to the people it serves.\n\u00a0\nFrom its founding as a Land Grant institution in 1867 focused on agriculture and engineering, through expansions into arts, graduate studies, and national and international collaborations, the University has maintained a mission to deliver education and research in service to society. In Knowledge at Work, we look at the role of the University of Illinois as a nexus for bringing together people with diverse backgrounds, perspectives, and experiences in a common pursuit. The background and needs of students and faculty have changed over time, inspiring new facilities, curricula, and services.\nOn display are artifacts, documents, and photographs from throughout the University\u2019s history: books from the first library collection, a course schedule from 1877, panels from early ILLIAC computers, and Olympian Jean Driscoll\u2019s racing chair.\nThe exhibit is accompanied by a series of events for all ages: talks, exhibit tours with the curator, family hands-on activities, and historic campus walking tours. Visit the Museum\u2019s website to learn more http://www.spurlock.illinois.edu/events/#ui150.\nKnowledge at Work runs September 12, 2017\u2013December 21, 2018 and was developed in partnership with the University of Illinois Archives.",

    {
        "Title": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nThe University of Illinois Russian Folk Orchestra was founded in 1974 by John Garvey, who had joined the University\u2019s Walden String Quartet in 1948 as its violist and in 1959 established the university\u2019s jazz band program.\u00a0 In 1969, the jazz band toured the Soviet Union as part of the State Department\u2019s cultural exchange program, and Garvey developed a keen interest in Russian folk music.\u00a0 He later returned to the USSR to study Russian folk music traditions and purchased additional folk instruments that he used to establish the Illinois Russian Folk Orchestra.\u00a0 The Illinois ensemble eventually served as a model for other American universities\u2019 Russian folk orchestras by providing open depoliticized educational spaces for students to pursue their interest in Russian folk music traditions.\u00a0 This exhibit of folk instruments, photographs, and music provides visitors with a general introduction to Russian folk music traditions and culture that were promoted by the Soviet Union after the Russian Revolution and the folk musicians who immigrated to the United States after WWII.\u00a0 It also acknowledges many of the talented musicians who performed with the University of Illinois\u2019 Russian Folk Orchestra under Garvey\u2019s direction between 1974 and 1989 and reveals a forgotten part of the University of Illinois\u2019 musical past.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",
        "Event Type": "\u201cFrom Russia with Love:\u201d John Garvey\u2019s Russian Folk Orchestra",

        "Title": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nThe University of Illinois Russian Folk Orchestra was founded in 1974 by John Garvey, who had joined the University\u2019s Walden String Quartet in 1948 as its violist and in 1959 established the university\u2019s jazz band program.\u00a0 In 1969, the jazz band toured the Soviet Union as part of the State Department\u2019s cultural exchange program, and Garvey developed a keen interest in Russian folk music.\u00a0 He later returned to the USSR to study Russian folk music traditions and purchased additional folk instruments that he used to establish the Illinois Russian Folk Orchestra.\u00a0 The Illinois ensemble eventually served as a model for other American universities\u2019 Russian folk orchestras by providing open depoliticized educational spaces for students to pursue their interest in Russian folk music traditions.\u00a0 This exhibit of folk instruments, photographs, and music provides visitors with a general introduction to Russian folk music traditions and culture that were promoted by the Soviet Union after the Russian Revolution and the folk musicians who immigrated to the United States after WWII.\u00a0 It also acknowledges many of the talented musicians who performed with the University of Illinois\u2019 Russian Folk Orchestra under Garvey\u2019s direction between 1974 and 1989 and reveals a forgotten part of the University of Illinois\u2019 musical past.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",
        "Event Type": "Illinois\u2019 Anti-Establishment Soundscapes: Troubled Waters in 1970",
        "Sponsor": "Sousa Archives and Center for American Music",
        "Location": "Sousa Archives and Center for American Music, 1103 S. Sixth Street, Champaign",
        "Date ": "Oct 30, 2017 - Oct 29, 2018 \u00a0  All Day ",
        "Cost": "No Cost",
        "E-Mail ": "217-244-9309",
        "Phone ": "129",
        "Views": "Library Calendar",
        "Originating Calendar": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nDuring the late 1960s many university campuses across America experienced significant political and social turmoil.\u00a0 For the University of Illinois the spring of 1970 was a time of tremendous political unrest among students and faculty regarding America\u2019s involvement in the Vietnam war, the US Department of Defense\u2019s construction of the Illiac IV supercomputer on campus, the Champaign-Urbana police force\u2019s killing of an unarmed African American student on the Illinois campus, and the Ohio National Guard\u2019s shooting of four students on the campus of Kent State University. \u00a0\u00a0While Illinois\u2019 students and many of its faculty frequently came together at this time to protest the Federal government\u2019s growing political oppression and imperialism, the campus\u2019 activists and protestors used many different music genres to convey their messages across the Urbana-Champaign campus.\u00a0 Music groups like the Campus Folksong Club, the Walden String Quartet, Medicare 7, 8, or 9, and REO Speedwagon as well as many faculty members from the University\u2019s School of Music frequently lent their musical talents to support these political and social protests. \u00a0This exhibit of photographs, news clippings, advertisements, protest broadsides, concert programs, graphic illustrations, and audio recordings highlight the diverse intersections of music, art, and protest on the Illinois campus during the 1970 school year.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",

        "Title": "Aug 21, 2017 - Aug 6, 2018 \u00a0  All Day ",
        "Event Type": "No Cost",
        "Sponsor": "217-244-9309",
        "Location": "307",
        "Date ": "Library Calendar",
        "Cost": "2017 American Music Month Exhibit\nThe Russian imperial capital of St. Petersburg was a major stop during John Philip Sousa\u2019s 1903 tour of Europe.\u00a0 Sousa planned his St. Petersburg performances to coincide with the tsar\u2019s birthday and the bicentennial of the city\u2019s founding, and anticipated large audiences for these concerts because the band had never before played in Russia.\u00a0 What resulted, however, was a misadventure.\u00a0 The concerts occurred at the beginning of Russia\u2019s annual summer vacation when most theaters and concerts halls were closed.\u00a0 In addition Russian music critics\u2019 responses to his music was tepid.\u00a0 Sousa was intimidated by the extensive advertising throughout the city for what he initially believed to be his music rival \u0421\u0443\u0437\u0430, but eventually discovered that this was the Russian spelling of his own name. \u00a0\u00a0While the St. Petersburg performances were not well attended, the concerts did spark deep patriotism among the American diplomats who were able to attend and the Russian aristocracy and military enthusiastically received the Sousa Band\u2019s renditions of the Imperial Russian and American national anthems.\u00a0 This exhibit of photographs, music, newspaper reviews, and political cartoons document Russian perceptions of America and Sousa\u2019s music at the beginning of the twentieth century.\nFor more information, please visit\u00a0https://archives.library.illinois.edu/sousa/american-music-month/.\u00a0",
        "E-Mail ": "Sousa and Tsar Nicholas II\u2019s Birthday: An Unexpected Tour Adventure",
